name: Building Your Home
description: Hello hello there! My name is Daisy, and I'm a Decorator, Designer, Developer....some other things that aren't as important, but my main passion is Designing and Decorating! I'm known as Decorator Daisy, and I can help you spruce up your Home slash Base slash Cave, and make it feel more comfortable! Step on in...

quests.name: A Fashionable Greeting
quests.description: Hm hm hmmm, Bitsy passed on to me that an assistant is stuck in another world, possibly alone and...well, they could use all the help they can get! I take it that is you? Of course it is, it has your name right here on my QUEST Tablet : Bandit, Very Lost Assistant. Don't worry, it's not saying you don't know anything, just the name we give Assistants who are kind of...unretrievable. You aren't exactly the FIRST assistant The Ferret Business has teleported out of reach. But fret not my fine ferret, with my help you'll be putting your own mark on that world yet! In fact, why don't you make a sign so you can proclaim it yours?

tasks.longDescription: By crouching when you place a sign, you can lay it flat on the front of a chest, flat on the ground, or even flat on the ceiling!

quests.name: Bibliocraft
quests.description: A house is not a home unless it has that...personal...touch, I say. Whether its a shelf full of treasured knicknacks, a favorite picture on the wall, or just simply a desk to call your own and a bookshelf full of novels. To make your house a home, I know of a lot of different bits of furniture and decorations that look spectacular. Not only that, most everthing is functional in some way as well! Now to start, lets make this cute little desk bell. Its useful if you plan on running a hotel desk or a shop counter, otherwise its just a cute adornment.

tasks.longDescription: You can ding the bell by Right Clicking it, or by sending a Redstone Signal to it!

quests.name: A Grand Timepiece
quests.description: A digital clock is all well and good, easy to read at a glance, but it doesn't have much...well, style, does it? Sure sure, fancy fonts and decorative frames are possible, but sometimes tried and true classics give the best style to a situation! The Grandfather clock is elegant and really stands out in a room. The clock face shows you the local time, while the pendulum (the little swinging thing) is synced to us here in The Ferret Business, ticks every Real second.

tasks.longDescription: You can make it twice as tall by stacking one on top of another, then Sneak + Right Clicking each Clock with a Screwgun or Hand Drill.

quests.name: No Writer's Block
quests.description: Given that you are kind of stuck in that world for a while, I bet you have a ton of things to write, right? Notes maybe, instructions to yourself or other assistants you may have found. Or heck, books, entire novels just swimming in your head, and now the time to write them...well, when you aren't clawing and scraping about to survive. I have a lot of beautiful and useful furniture you can make use of!

tasks.longDescription: Even in this age of Computers, there is something lovely about an old Typewriter. You can place a pile of papers into it, and then tap away at the front to type up a novel! Or, you can hire a ghostwriter! Give some creature or animal a name with a Nametag, then plop them in front of the typewriter! Just note that...what they write maaay not be all that legible...

By combining the functions of a Bookcase and a Crafting Table, you can not only save space, but also work better! With a normal Book, you can write a recipe to it on this, then place it onto the built in Shelf (or any book for that matter!)

The Typesetting Table allows you to copy Signed Books onto Printing Plates, to make a copy of later. Hold the book and right click it onto the lower left spot on top of the table. You can then Sneak + Right Click it to turn it blue and save it. Hold and Right Click a Printing Press Chase into the spot near the back of the tabletop, then right click the gray areas to the left or right of the Chase. You can select a saved book here, and then apply a Redstone Signal to the Typesetting Table to copy the book to the Chase.

The Chase you just made can be taken to this Printing Press. Right Click it onto the center area to put it in, then Right Click some Ink Sacs near it to apply Ink to the Press. Take a regular Book (not a Book and Quill or a written Book), and Right Click it onto the lower left countertop to place it there. When all three items are in the Printing Press, it will start working to make a copy of the book. When the book turns Blue, you can pick it up!

quests.name: Elegant Display
quests.description: Nothing makes better decor than showing off your curios. Simple things like a pretty stone, to complicated things like a Nether Star, can be shown off equally well in the right circumstances. I have a wide array of shelves and ways to show off your collections.

tasks.longDescription: These Bookcases are much more elegant than your vanilla Bookshelf. You can store up to 16 different books on this by Right Clicking a book onto it to place it in that spot, and later grab it off by Sneak + Right Clicking the book with an empty hand. For Enchanting purposes, every 8 books on a Bookcase counts as a single Bookshelf.
Each Shelf can hold up to 4 stacks of items. Place them on the shelf by Right Clicking one of the four spots, and you can remove the item again by just Right Clicking it.
You can Right Click almost any tool to place it up on this Rack. Right Click it again to remove it.

If you are a wiz Alchemist, you probably have a big pile of Potions about. These Shelves are great for storing and displaying them. Each one can hold 12 Potions for you! Simply place them or remove them with a Right Click.

If you have a unique, single special item you'd like to display, why not make a Case just for it? These fancy cases can be opened by Sneak + Right Clicking them with an empty hand, then the item placed inside. Sneak + Right Click again to close the case and secure the display.

Sometimes old school goodness can really improve a room. If you have old Jukebox Music Discs, you can place them in this Disc Rack to display them nicely. You can place these on the floor, the wall, or even the ceiling, and rotate them around by holding a Screwgun or Hand Drill and Sneak + Right Clicking.
Dinnerware is a fancy, timeless thing to add to any dining room. These Plates are large enough to hold three different food items, and can be eaten off of directly.

This Cookie Jar should be a staple in all kitchens. It's a special one, in that any item put into it will show up as a Cookie on the outside, making it a fantastic place to hide something. It even emits a Redstone signal when the jar is opened, to make a trap to catch Cookie thieves!

quests.name: Painted Dreams
quests.description: Wooden walls, stone walls, wallpaper, all of it is nice but tends to be kind of monotonous in large rooms, no? I like to break up large, empty expanses of walls with Paintings! They come in lots of sizes, with a wide range of designs you can choose from!

tasks.longDescription: You'll need a proper canvas to start with, something to  print the design onto.

Take your Painting Canvas and place it into this Press. You can choose from a nice selection of Paintings to print onto it. You can't place this directly on the wall yet, you'll need to make a frame for it.

There are a bunch of different ways to frame your Paintings on the wall. You can make a  Borderless one so it looks like a poster, or you can make varying style of frames to place the Painting into. I'll only ask you to make two of them, though, don't worry!
Know what else looks fantastic on a wall? A map, of course! You can use these Map Frames much like the Painting Frames, but they have the added bonus of being useable with a few fantastic tools...

When you have a map up on a Map Frame, you can use the Drafting Compas to mark locations on it. With the Waypoint Compass, you can use it on a waypoint you marked with the Drafting Compass, or Sneak + Right Click it to enter coordinates and the Compass will point towards it.

quests.name: Warrior's Pride
quests.description: To a fighter, a lot of his arms and armor are more about helping him survive than they are about looks...but thats perfect, as they tend to LOOK good as well. Symmetrical armor, a lot of layers, textures, all of it combined look fantastic. You can proudly show off your gear with these stands.

tasks.longDescription: You can display various outfits on this stand. Right clicking will open up an interface where you can place the armor, but if you Sneak + Right Click instead, you'll swap whatever you are wearing (even if its nothing!) with the armor piece you click!
You can place almost any sword into this pedastal to display it. When it is holding a sword, it emits a Redstone Signal, which is great for creating showy light effects on cue.

quests.name: Informational Fancy
quests.description: Not my usual way to spruce up a place, but using Signs and Labels can be quite helpful, and who says these things can't also LOOK nice as well? Made with the various types of wood, you can get these to fit into any decorative theme, I feel.

tasks.longDescription: A sign on a chest tends to get in the way when you are labeling things. This little label is quite handy, as it doesn't cover the front of the Chest. Open the interface by Right Clicking it with an empty hand.

The Fancy Sign is wonderful, you can customize the text on it in various ways, and even display a couple items on it! Sneak + Right Click it with an empty hand to open up the interface, which explains everything.

quests.name: A Hip Style
quests.description: Glasses...well, they tend to fade in and out of style, really. Sometimes they are out of style and you should probably wear contacts, other times the old school Monocole is best. For us, Glasses are ALWAYS in, as they are quite helpful in pointing out small things with many of these decorative things I'm showing you.

tasks.longDescription: When worn, Glasses, Tinted Glasses, and Monocoles will pop up text of any item in a Bibliocraft block, such as the name of a Book in a Bookcase, what Potion on a Potion Shelf, etc.
You can give a stylish tint to your Reading Glasses quite easily.
You can also make a Monocole for a more high-brow look.
What better way to show your style than by making something unique? You'll need a Framing Saw to start with, then you can combine it with any kind of Plank to make Framing Boards and Sheets.

You can use Framing Sheets in place of Wood Planks and Framing Panels in place of Slabs in a recipe to make a Framed version of the furniture. You can then place it into a Furniture Paneler, and design it with almost any Solid Block texture.

quests.name: Special Editions
quests.description: Books contain so much knowledge. They can also contain much, much more! Our bookshelves can be filled with endless storybooks and instruction manuals, but there are a couple of very special books we can fill them with as well, each one doing something different.

tasks.longDescription: For when a regular Book isn't big enough or fancy enough, the Big Writing Book lets you have multiple chapters, fancy text, and much more!
The Slotted Book looks like a signed book and can be renamed. Only instead of a story, it contains a single item slot within it.

When placed in a Bookcase, this book emits a Redstone Signal at the strength of the slot its put in. If put in the upper left, it emits no signal, but the lower right slot emits full strength. Don't forget you can rename this in an Anvil!

If you like drawing maps while exploring, you eventually come to the point where you are holding more maps than actual tools...Thats where the Atlas comes in! It can hold, display, organize, and even draw up new maps for you! You can also enchant the Atlas, and if you die, you'll reappear with an Eternal Compass that will guide you back to your stuff!

quests.name: Enlightened
quests.description: Being able to see in the dark is quite useful, and we can't all wear fancy night vision goggles. They aren't very stylish anyways. What IS stylish, though, are metal Lamps, especially in Gold! All of these lamps look slightly different whether you place them on the floor, the wall, or the ceiling. They can also be colored various colors with a bit of dye!

tasks.longDescription: You can make the lamps out of either Iron or Gold.
You can make the lantern out of either Iron or Gold.

quests.name: Handy Tools
quests.description: Decorating isn't all just pointing and color matching, a lot of it requires special tools. Does this room have enough space for a bed? Did we get all the furniture we wanted? And so on and so on. All these tools I use regularly and should be quite helpful to you as well!

tasks.longDescription: The Tape Measure helps you measure distances between two points. Right Click it onto the first block, then on the second block to see how far the two are from each other. You can also rotate items on tables with this by Right Clicking it onto one of the sides of the table.
The Clipboard allows you to make multiple lists and check them off. Handy when you have a big project going.

The Screw Gun and Hand Drill do the same things. They can rotate most Bibliocraft and Vanilla blocks when Sneak + Right Clicking. Many Bibliocraft blocks can also be changed just by Right Clicking them with one of these tools.

Not sure how deep that ocean is, or how far to the ground that jump is? Break out a Plumb Line and find out! Stand right in front of the drop you want to measure the depth of and Right Click with this item. It'll tell you how far down the next solid block is.

quests.name: Your Table Awaits
quests.description: Standing, its all well and good, but after a while its quite tiring. Especially if you are trying to do something like...say eat dinner or read a book or write a book or...well, lots of things! Thankfully you have plenty of options for both sitting and working, from desks and tables to chairs and thrones. A wide range of styles and options to choose from!

tasks.longDescription: Tables are handy for placing items on by simply Right Clicking them onto the table. You can then rotate them by Right Clicking a Tape Measure on any side of the table. You can also add a tablecloth by right clicking the top with a Carpet, or add a rug by Right Clicking the side of the table with the Carpet. You can remove a tablecloth by Right Clicking the top with a Screwgun or Handsaw, and a Rug by Sneak + Right Clicking the side of the Table with a Screwgun or Handsaw.

You can place Books down on this desk by Right Clicking them either on the back left or right corners to stack them, or the center to place an open book. You can grab a book by Sneak + Right Clicking with an empty hand. A Typewriter set on the desk will automatically stack finished Books onto one of the two stacks.

You can upholster these seats by Right Clicking it with a colored Carpet. You can connect multiple seats together by holding a Screwgun or Hand Drill and Sneak + Right Clicking each one you want to connect together. Repeat the process to disconnect them.

There is a wide array of of options when you want to add a back to your Seats. You can rotate which way the back is facing by Sneak + Right Clicking the legs of the Seat with a Hand Drill or Screwgun. You can remove the Seat Back and the Upholstery by Sneak + Right Clicking the top of the Seat.

quests.name: Carpenter's Blocks
quests.description: You know, in architecture, the common 'style' has been squares. Right angles. Rectangles. Anything with a 90 degree angle. Steps are just small stacks of squares. Even 'round' buildings are made with columns of square blocks, just arranged in a circle. Practical, but...boring. I think we can add a little pizzazz to any building just by embracing the odd angle.

tasks.longDescription: It all starts...with a square. Yes, I know, I talk about angles and slopes, but it all stems from the core structure of a Carpenter's Block.

quests.name: A Carpenter's Tools
quests.description: Now, those Carpenter's Blocks I showed you how to make are special. You can Right Click any other solid block onto it to apply it as a Cover. Carpenter's Blocks, and many other blocks you can make WITH Carpenter's Blocks, like Carpenter's Stairs, have Side Covers, which can be placed on top of normal covers. Each "side" that can have a cover can be customized with a different block, and further customized with a chiseled texture if you Right Click a Carpenter's Chisel on it. You can remove any Cover on a block by Sneak + Right Clicking the Cover with a Carpenter's Hammer.

tasks.longDescription: The Hammer is useful not just for removing Covers, but for customizing almost any Carpenter's Block. By Right Clicking the Hammer on a block, you can cycle through its 'styles'. You can then rotate the block around by Left Clicking on the block with the Hammer.
Want a design to POP more with some texture? Take out your Carpenter's Chisel and Left or Right Click on a Carpenter's Block that has a Cover on it.

quests.name: More Construction Options
quests.description: Now, Carpenter's Blocks can be knocked into half slabs with a hammer, but that can bring your designs only so far, you know? You have a variety of stairs and slops you can use as well! Not only that, you can put an Overlay on many of these blocks! Overlays add another layer of design to your builds, just Sneak + Right Click one of these items onto the block to add it as an Overlay.                                         Seed for Grass                          Snowball for Snow                       Vine for Vine                              String for Web                            Wheat for Hay                            Mushroom for Mycellium

tasks.longDescription: Stairs and Slopes will automatically try to orient themselves if you Right Click them against the face of a Carpenter's Block. If this orients them oddly, you can hold Sneak when Right Clicking to prevent this.

Slopes have a wide variety of designs. You can cycle through them after placing them with a Hammer like usual, but you can also hold them in your hand, hold Sneak and use your Mouse Wheel to cycle through them.

Want finer control of the slopes? Place down some of these Collapsible Blocks and Right Click a corner or quadrant to lower it, or Left Click to raise it. It'll try to keep an even transition between blocks, but you can hold Sneak when raising or lowering a block to ignore this ability.

Carpenter's Barriers will automatically create posts at intersections and corners, and you can force a post connection by Left Clicking the barrier with your Carpenter's Hammer. You can cycle through fence styles by Right Clicking with your Hammer, but the normal Fence style can have the board depth changed by Sneak + Right Clicking with your hammer.

quests.name: Quite Accessable
quests.description: Now, it wouldn't be much of a home if we couldn't get into it, now would it? Nor would it be stylish if we couldn't make these things match current trends either! Just like Carpenter's Blocks, Slopes, Stairs, etc, you can place Covers on these to customize them!

tasks.longDescription: Left or Right Click a door with your Carpenter's Hammer to cycle through the different door styles. You can also Sneak + Right Click to switch between Wood and Iron Door behaviour. If you switch to Iron Door behaviour, it will require a Redstone Signal to open.

A Garage Door needs to be placed underneath a solid block, where it will then extend down to the floor. If you open a Garage Door and there are other Garage Doors  next to it, all of them will open at the same time.
Just like the Carpenter's Door, Right or Left Click with a Carpenter's Hammer to cycle styles.
Like Carpenter's Barriers, Right Click with a Carpenter's Hammer to cycle styles, or Sneak + Right Click the normal gate style to change its plank depth.

Left Click on the Carpenter's Pressure Plate with a Carpenter's Hammer to switch Redstone polarity (whether it emits a signal when something IS or ISN'T on it). Right Click with the Hammer to change what triggers the Pressure Plate: either players, animals, monsters, or everything. The pressure plate can also be placed on any side of a block.
Left Click either of these with your Carpenter's Hammer to switch the polarity of the Redstone Signal. You can place either of these on any side of a block as well.

quests.name: Quite Homey
quests.description: Nothing makes a house a home more than decorating it to your own style. Your own bed, a pretty flower in a beautiful flowerpot, wall to wall eye catching designs, there are plenty of ways to give something your personal touch. Did you know you can also add Dyes to most Carpenter's Blocks as well? Take normal Vanilla Dye powder, and Sneak + Right Click the Dye onto the Carpenter's Block. Sneak + Left Click with a Carpenter's Hammer to get the Dye back.

tasks.longDescription: Cycle between Torch styles by Right Clicking with a Carpenter's Hammer. The uncovered style will randomly extinguish if it is out in the rain. You can either relight it with another torch, or wait until the rain stops and it will reignite itself.

Left Click with a Carpenter's Hammer to change Redstone Polarity. Right Click to change when the Sensor will trigger: Player Sleep (when it gets dark enough to sleep or light enough to wake), Monster Spawn (When the light enters or exits the level where monsters would spawn), or Sun Exposure (Redstone output depending on orientation of the sun compared to the orientation of the Sensor). You can place the Sensor on the side of a block, but it will be less sensitive to the light.

You can plant most things in the Carpenter's Flower Pot. Right Click inside the pot to place soil, then Right Click a seed on the Pot to plant it. You can Sneak + Right Click the plant to remove it, then the Soil to remove it as well. You can Sneak + Right Click to remove the Cover. Left or Right Click the Pot with a Carpenter's Hammer to cycle through designs (You cannot have both a Design and a Cover). You can also Fertilize some plants with Bone Meal, where they will take on a lively green color.

To Dye the frame of the bed, apply it to the Head of the Bed. To Dye the Blanket, apply it to the Foot of the Bed. If just coloring the Blanket isn't enough, Left or Right Click on it with a Carpenter's Hammer to cycle through some designs!

You can remove a tile by Sneak + Left Clicking them with a Carpenter's Hammer. Left or Right click them normally with the Hammer to cycle through designs, then Sneak + Right Click them to rotate the design. Unlike other Carpenter's Blocks, Dyes used on Tiles will not be consumed.

With your Carpenter's Hammer, Right Click a safe to set whether Pipes or similar Item Transport methods can extract or input items. Sneak + Right Click to Lock or Unlock the safe. When locked, the light on the front turns Red, and only you and server operators will be able to open or break the safe. The blue light strip designates what percentage of slots are used. You can upgrade the capacity by holding a Gold Ingot, an Emerald, or a Diamond and Sneak + Right Clicking the safe.

quests.name: Malisis' Doors
quests.description: Plain wood and metal doors are so...plain. And boring. We have so many stylish options for walls, ceilings, floors, furniture, why not doors as well? See, I know of a great designer known as M, who I've been talking with behind the scenes, and he's shown me some fantastic designs and given me great tips and tricks for designing eye catching doors!

tasks.longDescription: The first thing he showed me was a fantastic way to open doors without ever having to leave fingerprints on them! This can be placed on a wall next to a door, or connected to Redstone that leads to the door. When you or an assistant walks up to it, it'll send a Redstone signal, which will open the door upon your approach!

quests.name: Classical Doorways
quests.description: As much as I posture about being eye catching and unique, there still is a place for old school, reliable designs, with perhaps a little twist. As long as they fit the design of the rest of the building, that is. It'd be quite silly to have an old wooden door be the way into a high-tech laboratory, after all!

tasks.longDescription: These work just like their normal wood and iron counterparts, but instead of rotating on a hinge, they slide into the walll next to them!
These elegant doors are much like the sliding ones, except they slide open and close much slower.
Sometimes a solid door just isn't necessary. Fabric itself can lend a nice touch, giving a bit of privacy as well as style to a room.

quests.name: Specialty Doors
quests.description: Making lovely, unique doors for a domicile is one thing, but why don't we make some nice doors for a business or the like as well? If your work is as comfortable as your home, you work harder and longer and are more relaxed! Well, usually I would think.

tasks.longDescription: The Garage Door can be any size, as long as all the pieces are facing the same way. When you apply a Redstone Signal to any part of it, the entire door will slide upward as a single unit.
The Factory Door opens by splitting in the center and sliding both up and down.
The Laboratory Door slides upward when opened. It does not function as a double door.
The Jail Door opens by sliding sideways. It can also only be opened by a Redstone Signal.

quests.name: A Little Old, A Little New
quests.description: There's something to be said about really atmospheric builds. Using modern materials to build some sort of themed creation, making the outside of your house look like a submarine or a lighthouse or some super futuristic fortress. Using a normal door just wouldn't cut it for these.

tasks.longDescription: This rustic doorway comes complete with its own rusty ladders! It takes a lot of space, though, as you need room for the giant door to open. If you place it on the top half of a block side, it'll open upwards.
If you need to extend the ladder of the Rusty Hatch, or just want a more atmospheric ladder, you can make more Rusty Ladders.

The Forcefield Controller can make a Forcefield doorway of nearly any size (It has a limit of about 100 blocks). Right Click it on the side of the first block, then on the second block you want to create the Forcefield between. You can then turn the forcefield on and off with the Controller. Sneak + Right Click the Controller on the Forcefield to remove it instead.

quests.name: Truely Your Own
quests.description: There are a lot of different styles of doors for you to choose from, but sometimes none of them fit your decor just right. With the Door Factory, you can mix blocks together to make a custom door, selecting the material for the frame and the door itself. You can also choose how it opens, what sounds it makes, and more! Perhaps, though, you also want to customize your blocks? With the Block Mixer, you can blend two blocks together.  With both of these, you can use a Bucket of Water or a Bucket of Lava to have a 'flowing' texture of that liquid. You can also use an Ender Pearl to show a swirling Portal.

tasks.longDescription: On top of the other options, you can use a Flint and Steel to have a fire effect on the door as well.
When mixing blocks, if the block emits light, the custom block will too. Mixing in a Redstone Block will have it emit redstone. Non-opaque blocks like glass will make the block see-through.

quests.name: Here and Gone Again
quests.description: Sometimes, you want a door that's just different. Whether its a heavy solid door flush with the rest of the wall, or a door that looks just like the wall itself, hiding your entrance so only you know where it is, you have a lot of options with Vanishing Frames! Once placed, you can Right Click any block onto the Vanishing Frame to copy its looks. When a Redstone Signal is applied to one, it will propogate the signal to all connected Vanishing Frames, though in different ways depending on what type of Vanishing Frame you've got.

tasks.longDescription: The Wooden Vanishing Frame will transmit the Redstone Signal to neighboring frames of all types.
Iron will only propogate the Redstone Signal to other Vanishing Frames that are copying the same block.

Gold Vanishing Frames are like Iron, but will only propogate the signal to frames with the same Block and Metadata. This means If you activate one that looks like White Wool, it won't send the signal to one that looks like Green Wool.
Diamond Vanishing Frames let you customize all these behaviours, even include a delay before it propogates the Redstone Signal!

quests.name: Tails
quests.description: You know, sometimes its not just your home you can customize. What about yourself? Well, with the QUEST Tablet, you can customize yourself with a spiffy, fluffy tail! Or some cute wings or ears! Just hit ESC for the main menu, and at the bottom is a button to customize your look! Choose from a wide variety of tails, wings, and ears, color them to your liking, and even save them as an outfit!

quests.name: Chisel 2
quests.description: Take a simple piece of Stone...or is it so simple? There are so many different things you can do to and with a piece of Stone. You can arrange it in various ways. You can paint it various colors. You can shape it. You can also...Chisel it. With a simple Chisel and an eye for decoration, you can turn lots of simple, many times boring, materials into spectacular, eye catching fancies! All you need is your Chisel and a stack of materials!

tasks.longDescription: ((Search for Chisel from Chisel 2 in NEI))                                   Right Click your Chisel to get the Inteface. You can put a wide variety of blocks in the left side, to see what you can turn them into in the right. If you Chisel a block and place it back into the left slow, you can close the Interface and then Left Click the same type of block in the world to change it to that design!

quests.name: A Custom Home
quests.description: There are a lot of things you can do to spruce up both the inside and outside of your home. Unique carpets, unique walls, unique ceilings! Even make the gifts you give unique!

tasks.longDescription: Thread some String in Wool to make Carpet. The outside edges of placed Carpet will have a different design than the center.
You can combine two Carpet to make a Floor Carpet, also known as a Rug.
You can give Stained Clay walls a bit of a textured touch to them by adding Wool.
By surrounding a wooden Stick with Paper, you can get this thin, elegant wall material.
By combining a handful of the Paper Walls, you can make it into a box, widening your design choices.

quests.name: Naturally Custom
quests.description: There are plenty of naturally created materials you can harvest and Chisel, these three being some of the more interesting! They are not as common as Stone is, but can be found underground all the same.

tasks.description: And A Sight For Sore Eyes!

quests.name: Tossable Toys
quests.description: There's a few ways you can spruce up a build that doesn't involve taking your Chisel to it. These three 'toys' are quite different from each other, but be careful with them all the same!

tasks.longDescription: Bottling some Quartz in Glass gets you a Cloud in a Bottle. You can Right click it to throw it, and where it hits spawns a big, fluffy cloud! It is the only way to get special Cloud blocks to Chisel.
By wrapping Vines and Sticks together, you get a Ball of Moss. When Right Clicked to throw it, any Cobblestone the splash hits will be covered in Moss.
Combining a Stone Pickaxe and Shovel and putting them in a Glass Bottle (don't ask how!), you get something you can throw that will smash Stone to Cobble, Cobble to Gravel, and Gravel to Sand.

quests.name: A Custom Fantasy
quests.description: What if I told you that you could Chisel your way to a more fantastical life? Well, you can at least Chisel yourself a nice Fantasy setting. Your imagination is the limit with all these designs you can just picture being from stalwart dwarves, elegant elves, and mad overlords.

tasks.longDescription: Surrounding a Gold Nugget with Stone gets you this white marble and gold inlaid block. great for princely castles.
If your designs are less flashy and more spiritual, look no further than the Temple Block, obtainable by surrounding some Blue Dye with Stone.
By surrounding either a Bucket of Water or a Bucket of Lava with Stone, you get a pair of opposing blocks that look purely elemental.
If opposing elements isn't your fantasy, then how about the divine struggle? Surrounding a Feather with Stone gets you Holystone, while surrounding some Coal gets you Grimstone.
Beyond this mortal plane is the Void. Surrounding an Ender Pearl with Obsidian and Stone nets you this fantastically mesmerizing block.

quests.name: A Custom Road
quests.description: Inside the home and inside the office aren't the only places you can Chisel your own artistic touch : how about outside on the road? Theres a lot of sidewalk and street designs, plus many signs you can make!

tasks.longDescription: By smelting Gravel, you can make Concrete. This is fantasic material for both walkways and roadways.
What is a proper road without proper lines? Mix some Redstone with some White Dye to make an eye-catching guide.
Surrounding a Sign with Stone lets you make an very noticeable warning sign!

quests.name: Improved Chisel Tools
quests.description: Your basic Iron Chisel is great and all, but it eventually wears out. Not to mention, if you are making a BIG construction, thats a whole lot of things you need to Chisel. By hand. My fingers hurt just thinking about it! Well, here's a set of advanced tools that should really help you out!

tasks.longDescription: The Diamond Chisel has a few distinct advantages. One, it lasts longer, thats for sure. Two, you can change Modes on it to Chisel larger amounts of placed blocks at once!
The Auto Chisel does what it says on the tin. You can place a Chisel into it, a basic material, and the Chiseled variation you want, and it'll slowly, steadily Chisel them for you!
The Speed Upgrade speeds up how fast the Auto Chisel works.
Normally, the Auto Chisel does not allow you to pipe or transport items into or out of it via pipe or other method. That is, unless you have the Automation upgrade.
Why Chisel things one at a time? The Stack Upgrade makes the Auto Chisel work on entire stacks of materials at once!

quests.name: A Custom Workplace
quests.description: How truely efficient is a workplace if it doesn't look and feel like a fantastic place to spend a third of your day in? Not that efficient, I'd say! If your workplace looks like every other concrete and wood, cookie cutter box, then how can you put 100% effort into your job? Well, you can Chisel your way to a nicer work environment!

tasks.longDescription: Laboratories are well known for their pristine, uniform walls that are easy to clean and maintain. Surrounding some Quartz with Stone will give us this clean look.
Looking for something less futuristic and a little more modern? Combining Stone and Iron nets you a Technical look, complete with giant fans, wires, and more.
Switching a bit of Stone for Glass, you can make some Technical blocks with transparency in them.
If you want to go back a bit to the rise of Industry, look no further than the Factory block. A little less Stone, and you have more rustic looking metal parts!
Surrounding Redstone with Stone gets you a much more Futuristic set of blocks.
For that futuristic Armored look, the Tyrian block gives you lots of options. Just surround an Iron Bar with Stone.
Another Futuristic look is to go Hexagonal. By surrounding a Coal Block with Stone, you get Hex Plating that looks amazingly futuristic.

Need to light an area to see in, but not, you know...ACTUALLY light it? Well, surround some Glowstone Dust with Stone and you'll get an Anti Block. It illuminates very brightly...but only itself. If you put it in a pitch black room, you can see only it clearly...and anything else that walks between you and it. You could probably use this for a greenscreen!

quests.name: Armourer's Workshop
quests.description: Designing your home, designing your work, designing your games...what is left? Well, designing your wardrobe of course! And not just as a fashion statement, but as a way to protect yourself! What if you could make a spectacular, fancy hat that also doubled as a pair of magic goggles? Or a posh, frilly dress that also blocked zombie bites? Or how about a paper fan that was actually a razor sharp sword? The possibilities, as always, are endless! But we have to start somewhere...and that somewhere is called the Equipment Cube. This will allow you to make designs that 'replace' the look of many of your armor and weapons. It won't work on ALL armor and weapons...but a lot of them! Heck, you can even change the look of your Arrows and even Blocks!

tasks.longDescription: This is the Equipment Cube. You'll need a lot of them, but they'll be reusable for each project.

quests.name: A Better Forge
quests.description: Now that we have some basic Equipment Cubes, we'll need a 'forge' to use them in. And by forge, I don't mean a hot smelter and an anvil. No, this is much more fashionable! You'll be crafting this armor yourself, as if you were building a house. Don't look at me like that, you'll understand soon! You'll need a nice big area, I'd say at least 50x50x50 blocks big. And a ton of Equipment Cubes, you cannot use any other material in your designs, sorry!

tasks.longDescription: When you place this down, be ready for a BIG surprise! Okay, now that the shock is over, you can see, well, your own head on an epic scale! This way, you can hand-craft the look of your armor and weapons as if you were constructing a building. You can select the different parts of the body you want to design for.

You will need somewhere to save your design, which we call a Skin. The Skin Template can be placed in the Armourer, a name typed in, and when you are done building with Equipment Cubes, you can save the design to the Template. You can now Wear your design! You'll probably have to rebind your Armor Skin screen though...I suggest the Minus key!
The Equipment Library is where you can save and load Skins from your hard drive (or the server you are playing on). There are some basic Skins already available for you to chose from!

While one way of applying skins is your Skin Equipment menu, sometimes you want a skin to be specific to a piece of armor. The Skinning Table allows you to apply a Skin to some pieces of equipment. Then when you or anyone uses it, it will have the skin instead!                  To remove the Skin from the equipment, combine it with Soap in your Skinning Table.

quests.name: Expanded Materials
quests.description: Basic Equipment Cubes are only the start! You can design your Skins with transparent Equipment Cubes as well! Not only that, how about glowing versions? Fabulous!

quests.name: In Living Color
quests.description: On their own, Equipment Cubes give shape to your Armor and Weapon designs...but are kind of boring. They are a single, uniform color, which is where all these tools come in!

tasks.longDescription: To apply color, you're going to need some brushes to start with. The basic Paint Brush will color one Equipment Cube at a time, while the Paint Roller will cover a 3x3x1 area.

To get the Color you want, you'll need a Colour Mixer. You can adjust the color setting in it, then place either a Paint Brush or Paint Roller in the top right slot to apply it. You can also hold one of these Brushes and Sneak + Right Click it on the Colour Mixer itself to copy the color.
You can Right Click this Colour Picker to copy the color on any Equipment Cube. You can then either place it, or Sneak + Right Click it, on a Colour Mixer to copy the colour to it.
Each of these tools can be used to add various color enhancements to your Equipment Cubes. You can Sneak + Right Click each one to set the Intensity of its function.

You may have noticed in the Colour Mixer, that you can choose the Type of Dye, between Normal, Dye 1 through 8, and None. When you are creating a Skin, you can apply a Type to a tool, and if it is a Dye #, you will see Dots on the Equipment Cubes.                              This will let you set your Skins to have different Dyeable sections. When you create a Skin, you can designate some or all the blocks to be dyeable. If you made a sword, you could make the Handle Dye 1, Blade Dye 2, and decorations Dye 3.     You will then need to fill Dye Bottles with the colors you want, and bring the Bottles and Skin to the Dye Table, where you can see how the dyed colors look before accepting it.

quests.name: A Fine Display
quests.description: You know, you can make all kinds of Skins...but you can only wear one set at a time! Just stashing them in a box doesn't seem right, so how about making a Mannequin for them? You can pose it and place any Skin Templates on it to customize it. You can even have it mimic someone's clothing by putting their name on a Name Tag in an Anvil, and then Right Clicking the Tag onto the Mannequin.

tasks.description: Did it Turn to Look at Me?!

quests.name: DecoCraft
quests.description: There are a lot of things that make a house a home, or a workplace a business, or a lab a laboratory. To me, its the little touches that matter. A kid's room doesn't seem fun without some stuffed animals, nor does a lab look scientific without some beakers, right? Well, you can make all these little accroutements from a simple material called Crafting Clay!

tasks.longDescription: A little Sand, a little Dirt, and some Green, Red, or Blue dye is all you need! Even Monsters seem to love it, it can drop from many different creatures!

Now that you have some materials to work with, you can work them in a normal Crafting Bench, or you can make yourself a DecoBench!                                     The DecoBench can be filled with large amounts Red, Blue, and Green Crafting Clay, or even filled with the basic Clay and dye. You can then easily search and craft any of the hundreds of Decocraft items!

quests.name: Tons of Toys
quests.description: Toys are fun to look at, fun to collect, and tend to keep the little ones busy and out of your hair...at least until they break the toy. These, at least, are quire sturdy!

quests.name: Big Business
quests.description: Eye catching displays and tools of the trade are standard fare for businesses. What better way to show people what you sell than a big sign?

quests.name: A House a Home
quests.description: Nothing makes you feel more at home than being in a house full of things you love, be it people, possessions, or both!

quests.name: Worldly Wonders
quests.description: The world is a great big place, full of interesting things. Why not make some of them to show them off?

quests.name: Festive Fun
quests.description: Holidays and celebrations are a great time and a perfect excuse to go all out with decorations!
